title: Check my extension for make tab chaos manageable in Chrome
description:
I’m one of those people who always has way too many tabs open. Work stuff, docs, random articles, flights, tools… and then I lose the one tab I actually needed =) So I built a Chrome extension that replaces the New Tab page with a simple dashboard that automatically groups all your currently open tabs by website/domain.

It’s basically the view I always wished Chrome had.

What it does:

  • Groups open tabs by domain automatically (Google / GitHub / Notion / etc.)
  • Shows favicons + color-coded groups so it’s easy to scan
  • Jump to any tab instantly
  • Close a tab or a whole group in one click
  • Pin your “always-open” domains/groups
  • Search tabs by title / URL / domain
  • Light/dark mode
  • Remove duplicate tabs (I somehow always open the same page 3 times…)

And lovely cat that wake up when you open 50+ tabs. And Easter egg - it fails when you close group of tabs under the cat. Then it says some funny phrases.

Chrome Web Store: https://chromewebstore.google.com/detail/smart-tabs/inogfehnhcebnnojoifmabiccedlllpl

Would love feedback - especially from anyone who also lives with 50+ tabs open. Anything you’d change or add?
description_plain:
I’m one of those people who always has way too many tabs open. Work stuff, docs, random articles, flights, tools… and then I lose the one tab I actually needed =)
So I built a Chrome extension that replaces the New Tab page with a simple dashboard that automatically groups all your currently open tabs by website/domain.

It’s basically the view I always wished Chrome had.

*What it does:*

- Groups open tabs by domain automatically (Google / GitHub / Notion / etc.)
- Shows favicons + color-coded groups so it’s easy to scan
- Jump to any tab instantly
- Close a tab or a whole group in one click
- Pin your “always-open” domains/groups
- Search tabs by title / URL / domain
- Light/dark mode
- Remove duplicate tabs (I somehow always open the same page 3 times…)

And lovely cat that wake up when you open 50+ tabs. And Easter egg - it fails when you close group of tabs under the cat. Then it says some funny phrases.

Chrome Web Store: https://chromewebstore.google.com/detail/smart-tabs/inogfehnhcebnnojoifmabiccedlllpl

Would love feedback - especially from anyone who also lives with 50+ tabs open. Anything you’d change or add?

zerobrew is a Rust-based, 5-20x faster drop-in Homebrew alternative
description: zerobrew takes a lot of ideas from uv - packages live in a content-addressable store (by sha256), so reinstalls are instant. Downloads, extraction, and linking run in parallel with aggressive HTTP caching. It pulls from Homebrew's CDN, so you can swap brew for zb with your existing commands. This leads to dramatic speedups, up to 5x cold and 20x warm!
description_plain: zerobrew takes a lot of ideas from uv - packages live in a content-addressable store (by sha256), so reinstalls are instant. Downloads, extraction, and linking run in parallel with aggressive HTTP caching. It pulls from Homebrew's CDN, so you can swap brew for zb with your existing commands. This leads to dramatic speedups, up to 5x cold and 20x warm!

spreadsheets + vi + json
description:
Hi lobste.rs! I'd like to share a proof of concept for an idea I've thought about for a long time. Think of a new form of spreadsheets where the primary data structure is not a rigid grid but a free-form JSON-like structure (but with first class tables support of course). I'm linking here a demo which uses vi style hotkeys for interaction, although of course the idea is not limited to that mode of interaction.

The addresses end up being JSON paths. The layout is currently rigid because it's just a PoC but ideally you'd have much more control over it, kind of like a canvas.

Expressions can refer to other cells via their JSON based address, even relative to their current address. There is no expressions support in the PoC yet but a table in the example does show a dynamic column. Since you have arbitrarily nested arrays/hashes anyway, you can reserve tables to represent arrays of homogenous records, and some of the columns can be dynamically calculated (or have a default dynamic calculation) based on other columns. The expressions are just JavaScript functions, but they can be anything that works with JSON types.

This is very far from finished. I'm just been trying to share early these days and I think many of you'd find the idea itself interesting.

Why? I think spreadsheets are great but they are underutilized because of their rigidity. They are not suitable for version control, being authoritative data sources, powering APIs etc. I don't know if this is the right direction either. I'd be happy to hear your thoughts!

The code is 100% manually written by me (except for the CSS background which I copied from SO). If there is sufficient interest in collaboration, I'd be happy to put up the source on codeberg.

title: Gas Town’s Agent Patterns, Design Bottlenecks, and Vibecoding at Scale
How to think about Gas Town
I Was Right About ATProto Key Management
Frozen Insight in a Moving World
description:
I don't generally write a lot (i've got 3 more articles on different topics i'm fleshing out still, including one about building EWARS for the WHO, a large disease surveillance platform), but i've been pretty active in discussions around AI on here ranging from vocally against, to middling reluctant acceptance. I thought i'd try and put down what I was feeling and tried to find a way to frame it. I've seen a few articles cropping up that are framing technology around Pirsigs metaphysics of quality, but I felt like none of them really went deep enough to compare previous things.

I also wanted to share a timeline that doesn't result in complete and utter cultural and environmental collapse, despite being firmly in the anti-AI camp. I did try and be a bit more well-rounded here, and try and show what the concerns are with the stated pros of AI, and how the pushback isn't on the positive aspects, it's on what we have to trade in order to have those positives.

Edit: Added culture tag as it's more about overarching culture, technology culture, and where AI sits within it's evolution.
description_plain:

I thought i'd try and put down what I was feeling and tried to find a way to frame it. I've seen a few articles cropping up that are framing technology around Pirsigs metaphysics of quality, but I felt like none of them really went deep enough to compare previous things.

I also wanted to share a timeline that doesn't result in complete and utter cultural and environmental collapse, despite being firmly in the anti-AI camp. I did try and be a bit more well-rounded here, and try and show what the concerns are with the stated pros of AI, and how the pushback isn't on the positive aspects, it's on what we have to trade in order to have those positives.
